entry.title: Hello Python: My First Script in SAP BAS Connecting to HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Credit: @Vitaliy-R Your startup blogs kindled my interest to explore working with Python in SAP ecosystem. Python in BAS and Jupyter in BAS 

When I first started exploring SAP Business Application Studio (BAS), I was curious about how Python could fit into the SAP landscape. I‚Äôve mostly associated BAS with HANA artefacts(SQLScript, hdbcalculationview, hdbreptask etc.) and CAP artefacts, so writing a Python script inside BAS felt like venturing into new territory. My goal was simple: write a basic script and connect it to SAP HANA Cloud. What I discovered along the way is that Python not only works smoothly in BAS but also makes it easy to interact with HANA Cloud, opening up opportunities for data exploration, automation, and integration in a way that feels both modern and approachable.

Before jumping into the Python script, I had to get my environment ready in SAP Business Application Studio (BAS). Here‚Äôs what I set up:

A BAS dev space with a full-stack cloud application space since it supports multiple runtimes, including Python. I had a space with HANA Native Application type. Since the Python tools extension is not added by default, I edited the space to select the Python tools in the additional extension options. 

HANA Dev Space Python extension

 Note: For initial steps to check the Python version, Jupyter notebook and set ups refer to the blogs listed at the start. 

Use Case: I attempted to achieve the following: 

  • Establish a connection to HANA Cloud
  • Execute an SQL query on a table/view 
  • Display the results

In the BAS, I created a project from Template: SAP HANA Database Project

 

Next step: Create a notebook file. 

My guide to connect to HANA Cloud: Connect to HANA Cloud 

When I first tried importing hdbcli into my Jupyter Notebook within BAS, I ran into the same ModuleNotFoundError. Even though I had already installed hdbcli In the terminal, the notebook kernel wasn‚Äôt recognizing it. On some search and prompting with GPT( üòÅ), I understood that it's a common issue because Jupyter can run in a different Python environment than the terminal. The fix was simple: I ran

import sys
!{sys.executable} -m pip install hdbcli

directly in a notebook cell. This ensures that the HANA client is installed in the same environment as the notebook kernel. After this step, I could successfully import dbapi and connect to HANA Cloud without any errors. It was a small but important lesson about Python environments in BAS, especially when using Jupyter.

With the hdbcli package installed and working in my Jupyter Notebook, I was ready to write my first Python script to connect to SAP HANA Cloud.

In the next cell, I imported hdbcli in this notebook. 

import hdbcli
print(hdbcli.__file__)

 

 The next step was to gain access to the dbapi interface, which allows you to establish connections, execute SQL queries, and fetch results from your HANA Cloud instance. This simple import is the gateway to working with HANA directly from Python.

from hdbcli import dbapi

The next step is to establish a connection to your HANA Cloud instance. This requires specifying the host, port, username, and password.

 After connecting, you can create a cursor object to execute SQL statements. An SQL statement, preferably a Select Query to test the retrieval of data from HANA Cloud. In my case, I used a Select with count on the number of records in a view. Once the variables were ready, execute the connection cursor object.

Note: in the SQL variable, use single quotes and a semicolon at the end of the query. (beginner tip üôÇ )

Now is the time to test the data retrieval from the script and compare it with the Database Explorer.

Drum roll....ü•Å

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Hurray üéâ

Completing my first Python script in SAP Business Application Studio and connecting it to HANA Cloud was an exciting milestone. From the initial curiosity to the small hurdles like installing hdbcli in the notebook and finally seeing my script return results, every step felt like a mini victory.

That simple output from HANA Cloud made all the effort worthwhile and gave me a real sense of accomplishment.

This experience has sparked my curiosity to explore more complex queries, data analysis, and automation using Python in SAP.

I hope my journey inspires others to take that first step and discover how fun and powerful working with Python and HANA Cloud can be.

Chao.

entry.title: New course: Creating Promotions and Coupons in SAP Commerce Cloud
entry.content:
I'm Charis from SAP CX Product Learning team and I am happy to share some exciting news for SAP Commerce Cloud business users and consultants! A brand-new course has arrived on learning.sap.com:

Creating Promotions and Coupons in SAP Commerce Cloud 

Who actually needs this course?

This course primarily aims to teach Business Users how to set up and execute marketing activities using promotions and coupons in SAP Commerce Cloud. It is a beginner course, targeting students with very little prior SAP Commerce Cloud experience. As this is an entry-level course, it may also be suitable for consultants, developers, or administrators who need to learn the fundamentals of SAP Commerce Cloud functionality surrounding promotions and coupons. The duration of the course will be approximately 3 hours.  

Learning Objectives

At the end of this course, students will be able to create promotions and coupons in SAP Commerce Cloud, activate them, and show the execution on the storefront. They will understand how standard features of SAP Commerce Cloud can be utilized to create promotions and coupons to fit different scenarios, depending on their needs.

The course consists of 3 units:

  • Mastering Promotions in SAP Commerce Cloud: Participants will be able to create out-of-the-box promotions using standard conditions and actions, effectively apply priority and rule groups, and set up and execute promotions in SAP Commerce Cloud.
  • Boosting Promotions with Coupons in SAP Commerce Cloud: This unit teaches how to configure and manage various coupon types within SAP Commerce Cloud, building on previous knowledge of how to effectively use promotion rules in SAP Commerce Cloud.  
  • Executing Promotions in Special Scenarios: This unit explores planning and customizing how promotions appear to customers, using potential promotions to proactively engage shoppers, and leveraging customer coupons to boost support and satisfaction.

The course contains very informative content provided in text, diagrams, videos. At the end of each unit, you will be called to answer on quiz questions which will test your understanding on the topic.

The course is available for everyone and it's free! Complete this course and earn a verifiable SAP Authorized Badge on your learning profile!

entry.title: Universal Allocation - How to determine results on Profitcenter level
entry.content:
Dear experts,
with regard to universal allocation I understood that in context of Profitcenters, it is not possible to allocate amounts between Profitcenters with Primary / Secondary GL accounts respectively cost elements.
I think in ECC it was possible to use these accounts types for assessments / distributions (3KE5/4KE5) between Profitcenters as well.

My question is:

If I have for example 3 operating Profitcenters which represent product groups and one additional "corporate function" profitcenter which has all costs assigned from cost centers like admin, R&D etc., how can I allocate these costs to the operating Profitcenters? Should this be done with allocation cycles that use account type N? Because I think it is not efficient to split all these corporate function cost centers into cost centers that are assigned to corresponding Profitcenters for each product group (e. g. admin cost center is divided into admin cost center product group A // admin cost center product group B //  admin cost center product group C). 

It would be great to get your input here to have a feasible approach without inflate cost center structures.

Thanks a lot and best regards,

Max

entry.title: Re: How to create 2 input control filters dependent on ea...
entry.content:
@Neha311 

What is the larger goal of doing this setup? If it is to allow data input on valid combinations of profit center and project code, Better approach would be to use Validation rules based on attributes. 

If you want to use data based derivation by populating 0's which you need to be very careful then your DA should be based on IF condition check for group

IF[d/PROFITCENTERTEST].[p/GROUP]=[d/PROJECTCODETEST].[p/GROUP] THEN

DATA()=1*0

ENDIF

Make sure you are scoping every other dimensions of the model in MEMBERSET else you will get a data explosion.

Once fact data is set to 0 at valid combination you can set the input controls to cascading to get the desired behavior.

 

Another option is to use scripting to set the dependent input control which is project code in this case.

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: Create Outbound delivery in WM without stock (Public...
entry.content:
Hello @castin 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, it is not possible to merge multiple existing outbound deliveries into one. The ECC feature such as VGM1 is not accessible in the Public Cloud.

What you should do:

When creating a delivery, you can choose to either use 'Create Outbound Deliveries from Sales Orders' or schedule delivery creation in batches. If several sales orders share the same criteria, such as shipping point, customer, and delivery date, the system will merge them into a single delivery.

At the transportation and shipping stage, utilise Advanced Shipping and Receiving ASR or TM integration to consolidate multiple deliveries into a single freight unit or load for execution, while maintaining separate delivery documents.

If more stock arrives later, the system will generate a new delivery each time; it does not merge or update the original.

Merging outbound deliveries after they are created is not supported in Public Cloud EWM. If this is essential, you should submit a request through the SAP Customer Influence programme.

SAP Learning-Processing Outbound Deliveries

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: bapi_pr_create return error
entry.content:
Why you get the ‚Äúenter asset no.‚Äù error in BAPI_PR_CREATE is because, the BAPI is validating the account assignment for category A (asset). Even if you see the asset value during debugging, the BAPI will still error if any of the mandatory account-assignment fields or formats are missing or inconsistent for the posting context (company code, distribution line).

For Account Assignment category A, you should provide the following:

  • Asset main number (ANLN1): 12 characters, left‚Äëpadded with zeros.
  • Asset subnumber (ANLN2): 4 characters, left‚Äëpadded with zeros.
  • Serial no. (distribution line): Typically ‚Äú01‚Äù for a single account line.
  • Distribution basis: Either set
    • PRACCOUNT-QUANTITY equal to the item quantity, or
    • PRACCOUNT-DISTR_PERC = 100.
  • Item‚Äôs account assignment category: PRITEM-ACCTASSCAT = ‚ÄòA‚Äô and PRITEMX-ACCTASSCAT = ‚ÄòX‚Äô.
  • Date formats: All DATS fields must be internal format yyyymmdd (your Excel dd.mm.yyyy must be converted).
  • Company code consistency: The asset must exist in the company code derived from the plant on the PR item; otherwise the asset is ‚Äúnot found,‚Äù and the BAPI prompts for asset number.
  •

entry.title: Disable the multi line edit in SAP RAP application in Edit Mode
entry.content:
Hi Folks,

Working with S/4 HANA 2023 FPS03 version.

In an SAP RAP-based Fiori Elements LROP application with oData V4 version, there are two Object Pages involved.

List Report - Displays a list of Objects,  First Object Page - Upon selecting an object from the list, this page a table with line items related to child entities, based on the keys from the parent CDS view.

In the table toolbar on the First Object Page, there will be a Create button (enabled via an association with Create from Parent in the Behavior Definition). Clicking this button navigates to the Second Object Page for creation or update of the line items.

When users click Edit on the First Object Page, all the line items in the table become editable via multi-line edit. However, the requirement is to disable this multi-line edit functionality in the table on the First Object Page. Instead, users should:

Use the Create button to navigate to the Second Object Page to add new line items.

Click on individual rows in the table to navigate to the Second Object Page for updating existing items.

Kindly suggest, how to disable the multi line edit in Edit Mode. Any suggestions, really appreciate it.

Regards,
Venkatesh K

entry.title: Re: Test Data Refresh PRO to QAS - S4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi @csilva1 ,

If you want to achieve the same purpose and outcome of Test Data Refresh, this is the only way. Please think this way: you have tons of production data spread in different tables with predefined hundreds and thousands relationships. It is hard for you to manually extract these data and put into a new system (Test tenant) and still keep their integrity. We conduct data migration during system setup. That only covers partial data, mostly the master data.  The scale and complexity of data movement are different. The TDR helps you to build a replica of your entire production system in a test tenant. 

Regards,

George

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud V2 Q3 2025 Release Highlights
entry.content:
What is new in SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud version 2?  

Explore a selection of our new features in this blog post and join our webcasts for live demos and comprehensive insights into SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP Service Cloud V2 updates. 

Register for our Q3 2025 customer webcasts  

October 14 webcast 
SAP Service Cloud Version 2, Utilities and SAP Enterprise Service Management: Q3/2025 Release Overview 

October 16 webcast 
SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, Sales and Foundation topics: Q3/2025 Release Overview 

Join us at SAP Connect
Please also join us at the upcoming Customer Experience Connect where we showcase how the latest AI-infused SAP CX solutions optimize operations, generate action-ready insights, and deliver delightful experiences at every step of the customer journey. 
Learn more about the SAP CX portfolio here.

What is new in SAP Sales Cloud‚ÄØV2 

SAP Sales Cloud development continues to focus on enhancing key features and workspaces, embedded AI and generative AI, and improving lead-to-cash process automation. We have incorporated several new features designed to reduce manual tasks that traditionally arise between SFA and ERP processes. Our pace of innovation continues to accelerate, but customer feedback remains a critical aspect of our development. Here are a few of our release improvements that stem from customer requests and feedback.  

UI extensibility and mashup permissions  
Customer engagement can be nuanced and may require greater flexibility to meet ideal customer use cases. To support this, administrators now have greater flexibility configuring workspaces and using mashups to provide access for microphone, notifications, and clipboard. This allows for more seamless engagement and supports situations where use of voice commands or notification loop up is helpful, in addition to improving read/write from and to the system‚Äôs clipboard. 

Generative AI Contact and Individual Customer Duplicate Checks 
Maintaining clean and accurate sales data and records are critical for effective sales organizations but duplicate and redundant data remains a plague. Existing SAP Sales Cloud data quality tools do a great job cleansing and harmonizing data, but in situations where there are not exact matches or several spellings some users reported missed matches. The new generative AI duplicate check option throws a larger data analysis net and provides users with actionable results paired with AI driven confidence scores. This allows users to take appropriate action or drill down, ensuring that they can make informed decisions faster.  

Restriction rules for email templates 
Generative email creation linked with templates and user driven email templates can dramatically increase email outreach and response times, but for organizations with several organizational units and geographic locations the number of available options can become confusing for the end user. Now administrators can maintain restriction rules for templates, ensuring users only have access to the right subset of templates. This allows administrators the ability to refine by organizational unit and user role, helping end users quickly choose the right template for their customer engagement needs.  

 Field Query Configuration Improvements and UI Enhancement 

To improve usability and administrator experience, we have added a new tab for configuring field query attributes. Within ‚ÄòExtensibility Administration‚Äô, users can now sort, filter, and search for relevant attributes. The workspace provides a detailed breakdown and a ‚ÄòShow Limits‚Äô toggle. We plan to continue to enhance both extensibility and the ease of use for extensibility administration.  

What is new in SAP Service Cloud  

In SAP Service Cloud, we have incorporated several new features designed to reduce manual workloads, expedite issue resolution, and enhance the overall agent experience. In our upcoming webcast, we will showcase these innovations, along with a range of other advanced capabilities, illustrating how they can streamline operations and elevate customer service.  

Improve case categorization with Business Information Extraction in Cases

 In the previous webcast we introduced Business Information Extraction, an AI feature that enables you to automatically extract key information like product names and serial IDs from customer emails. Now we have expanded the use of Business Information Extraction to Cases and you can use the extracted data to automatically categorize cases for faster and more efficient handling 

Business Information Extraction in Cases 
 

Gain improved insights with enhanced interaction and resolution summaries (machine learning)   
There are new machine learning scenarios designed to enhance interaction and resolution summaries. Sentiment Trends and Sentiment Graph add insights to the interaction summary, allowing service agents to better understand the tone of the customer interactions. You can also add internal and external case notes which are used the AI-generated resolution summary to create a more detailed overview. 

Expedite issue to resolution with the direct integration with SAP Field Service Management  
The new direct integration with SAP Field Service Management simplifies the end-to-end service delivery from the very first customer contact all the way to onsite repair. With a smooth integration between contact center and field service you can shorten resolution time and fix the issue on the first visit.   
 

Utilities customer service: gain improved insights with external alerts and quick view for meters 
For utilities contact centers, we have added new features that bring important insights for customer service agents: 

  • External Alerts: You can now add external alerts to the premise and contract views. These alerts are created in SAP S/4HANA. 
  • Quick View for Meters: In the services or premise tab, you can quickly view all the details of a meter, including the device's location and device location notes. 

Create outbound letters quickly with the OpenText Document Presentment Service integration 
The integration enables agents to quickly create outbound letters using automatically prepopulated fields and brand-aligned templates. This feature allows for the swift creation of professional PDFs, which can be sent as email attachments to customers.


 

Creating outbound letters 

 

More information

For more details on the above release features, check out the following resources: 

  • SAP Sales Cloud V2 What‚Äôs New 
  • SAP Service Cloud V2 What‚Äôs New 
  • SAP Sales Cloud V2 Release Navigator single access point to release content 
  • SAP Service Cloud V2 Release Navigator 

 

Please share your feedback in a comment and follow our SAP Sales and Service Cloud topic page to connect with the community!

entry.title: Re: Monitoring of expiration date for S-users in SAP ME p...
entry.content:
Hi Pavel,

As described by 2928052 - S-user ID Lifetime information - SAP for Me, administrators are notified on the 1st of each month about all S-user IDs set to expire within the next 90 days. This notification is provided by default. 

Currently, there is no functionality to create a monitoring group for users where a designated email group for carrier administrators would receive expiration notifications a specific number.
However, if this feature would be beneficial for your organization, you can submit an enhancement request through the Feedback channel, as outlined in KBA 3156721 - How to give feedback or share ideas and requirements - SAP for Me .The feedback will be sent to the product team, who will review the customer feedback/requirements on a regular basis.

In the meantime, administrators do have the ability to mass extend the expiration dates for a group of S-user IDs. 

For further guidance on this process, please refer to the following Knowledge Base Articles:
2931034 - How to mass extend the Expiration Date for a group of S-user IDs - SAP for Me
2930885 - How administrators manage the Expiration Date for other S-user IDs - SAP for Me

If you have any additional questions or need further clarification, please feel free to let me know. I am happy to assist! 

Have a nice day!

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: enter a material for item 000010 message no. v1351
entry.content:
The error ‚ÄúEnter a material for item 000010 (Message no. V1351)‚Äù typically appears when the system is not able to determine the correct item category or schedule line category for the sales document line item.

Since you have already checked VOV4, VOV5, and the Item Category Group (NORM in MM), here are a few additional points to verify in your O2C setup:

  1. Material Master Data

    • Ensure the material is created in the relevant sales area (Sales Org, Distribution Channel, Division).

    • Check that the material has a valid Sales View, Basic Data, and is not flagged for deletion.

  2. Sales Document Type and Item Category Assignment

    • In VOV4, confirm the correct assignment between Sales Doc Type, Item Category Group (NORM), Usage, and higher-level Item Category.

    • Make sure there is no conflicting or missing entry that prevents item category determination.

  3. Schedule Line Category Determination (VOV5)

    • Verify that the schedule line category is properly maintained for the combination of Item Category + MRP Type.

    • If missing, the system might throw the error when trying to create the item.

  4. Configuration Dependencies

    • Check if the material requires additional settings like availability check, pricing procedure determination, or plant assignment.

    • Make sure the plant is extended in the material master and properly maintained in the sales document line item.

  5. Testing with Another Material

    • Try creating the same sales order with another standard material (same item category group NORM). If it works, the issue may be specific to the problematic material master.

If after these checks the error still persists, please share a screenshot of:

  • The sales order line item overview,

  • Your VOV4 and VOV5 configuration entries for the relevant combination,

  • And the material master sales views.

That will help narrow down whether the issue lies in master data or configuration.

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì September 2025
entry.content:
What‚Äôs New in SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì September 2025

As we approach the end of the third quarter of 2025, we are thrilled to present the third release of SAP HANA Cloud for the year. Certainly, this quarterly update brings many innovative features designed to enhance your experience with SAP HANA Cloud and drive business value.



Let‚Äôs explore the exciting new capabilities and improvements that have just been made available.

 

Innovations in SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database

Administration and Service Management

Bulk Alert configuration

Starting off strong, the Q3 release introduces bulk alert configuration. Building on previous alert configuration methods and REST API-based bulk management, alert rule sets offer a graphical interface for bulk alert configuration accessible to all administrators without API expertise. The feature also allows to create and save alert configuration templates, making it easy to reuse them across different instances.

Bulk alert configuration significantly enhances user efficiency by streamlining the alert setup process. Management of complex alert configurations becomes more scalable, while safeguarding that all instances are monitored effectively without the need for repetitive manual setup.

To learn more about this new feature, take a look at this blog post by our product expert Hai Zhang.  

Partition Advisor

The Recommendation App, housing all intelligent advisors for SAP HANA Cloud, hosts a new advisor, as we introduce the partition advisor with QRC3 2025. It helps maintain manageable partition sizes by automatically analyzing potential partition keys and methods (range versus hash). It provides recommendations on how to partition your data effectively and can apply these recommendations via an ‚ÄúApply‚Äù button to your tables.

The Partition Advisor saves time by automating the analysis of partitioning options and delivering actionable recommendations. It helps users identify tables that may exceed the limits, suggesting optimal repartitioning strategies. This not only improves query performance but also optimizes costs, ensuring that your data management remains efficient and scalable.

Find more information about the partition advisor in this help documentation. 

Support for 9 TB instances on Microsoft Azure

From now on, SAP HANA Cloud on Microsoft Azure supports large instances up to 9TB. Please note that the availability of these large database instances will vary depending on your selected region.

With the support for 9 TB instances on Azure, businesses gain the flexibility to scale up their databases as needed. It allows them to handle increased memory requirements, while ensuring that their database can keep pace with growing data demands. This scalability is crucial for maintaining optimal performance and supporting business growth.

Finding object dependencies in database objects

Dependencies are now shown in the properties page of schema objects such as tables, views, functions, and procedures in the database objects app.  This enables you to quickly examine the dependencies between objects. 

As seen below in the Database Objects app, the table CUSTOMER has an incoming referential dependency from the RESERVATION table and is referenced in a view and function.  A graphical dependency viewer is also available in the SAP HANA database explorer extension in SAP Business Application Studio or Visual Studio Code. 

Simplified Instance Provisioning

The SAP HANA Cloud provisioning wizard has been enhanced to enable users to select either a preset configuration, provide a JSON configuration, or to use a manual configuration when creating new instances. 


The preset configurations for SAP HANA databases include basic, minimum, maximum, last used, and most used, enabling a user to quickly choose a preset that closely matches their use case.  After filling in a few required fields such as instance name and password, the instance can be created.  Basic is sized to support additional features such as the document store, triple store, natural language processing, and the script and data provisioning servers.   

The JSON configuration option enables a user to create instances based on a JSON document that contains the settings of the instance.  This can be helpful if you wish to create multiple instances with very similar configurations. 

Finally, the manual configuration option enables a user to explore all the possible configuration setting using the instance wizard. 

 

SQL Console statement library

With the QRC3 release of SAP HANA Cloud, the statement library in the SQL Console of SAP HANA Cloud Central has the option to run and open multiple statements either in the current tab or in individual tabs.‚ÄØ  

Run will append the statements together and the results will be shown in separate result set tabs. 

Run in Individual Tabs opens each selected statement in its own SQL Console tab and executes it. 

Data Integration

Introducing the New Data Access Agent - connecting to Azure SQL Database & Snowflake

Additionally, I am thrilled to announce that SAP HANA smart data access (SDA) now supports Microsoft Azure SQL database and Snowflake as remote sources via the new Data Access Agent. This new Data Access Agent expands data federation and provides broader coverage with JDBC-based adapters as an SAP-managed service.

With a clean core strategy in mind, SDA is a core component to leverage the full potential of your data. Until recently, the limited protocol boundaries to ODBC and REST as well as restrictions on running 3rd party drivers, limited the supported scope of remote resources. SAP HANA smart data integration (SDI) helped to bridge this gap but required customers to deploy and operate the Data Provisioning Agent (DPAgent) in an on-premise setup.

The new Data Access Agent now supports new JDBC-based adapters. Of course, the natively available SDA adapters continue to be based on ODBC and REST. The SAP-managed Data Access Agent simplifies operations and reduces the effort to access Microsoft Azure SQL Database and the Snowflake in SAP HANA Cloud. Users can also benefit from streamlined and user-friendly configuration and monitoring of this fully managed, secure, and cloud native product.

Please note the new Data Access Agent currently only supports data federation and snapshot toggling within the virtual table interface. Real-time replication is not supported. Refer to further details of support in SAP Note 2600176 - SAP HANA Smart Data Access Supported Remote Sources.

To learn more about SAP HANA Cloud's New Data Access Agent, take a look at @SeungjoonLee 's  blog post here.

Support a remote source to SharePoint in Microsoft 365 

Moreover, with the Q3 release we introduce support for creating a remote source to SharePoint in Microsoft 365 using the data access agent of SAP HANA smart data access. This feature allows for the virtualization of data, including lists and Excel worksheets, within SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database. For further details on supported remote sources, refer to SAP Note 2600176.

With the ability to access SharePoint data in Microsoft 365 through the SAP-managed data access agent, users can simplify operations and reduce the effort required for data integration. This eventually enhances collaboration and streamlines data management processes.

Direct SQL access to files in the Apache Iceberg open table format

Furthermore, with the recent release we introduce direct SQL access to files in the Apache Iceberg‚Äôs open table format. This enhancement enables users to create virtual tables within SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database, allowing read-only access to Apache Iceberg data in external object storage. Supported storage types include the data lake files in SAP HANA Cloud, Amazon S3, Azure Blob Storage, Azure Data Lake Storage (ADLS) Gen2, and Google Cloud Storage.

This means users can execute SQL queries on large volumes of data without the need to load it into the memory of the SAP HANA database. The new feature thus enhances performance and efficiency, enabling seamless data analysis across diverse storage environments.

Security

Row-level data access control over fact tables based on associated dimension attributes

Next, SAP HANA Cloud now supports row-level data access control over fact tables based on associated dimension attributes. This allows users to restrict access to fact table data without the need to join the dimension tables where the access control is applied. Restrictions are based on the availability of associated dimensional data, which is already restricted with a structured filter (=nested structured filters).

This capability enables fine-grain access control to restrict data for fact tables based on associated dimension table attribute data. This enhances security and ensures that sensitive data is accessible only to authorized users, improving overall data governance.

Support for X509-based dynamic user creation

Moreover, SAP HANA Cloud also supports X509-based dynamic user creation, leveraging the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP). Customers can now create user data automatically in SAP HANA Cloud based on X509 authentication and manage user data within related LDAP groups.

Bridging the gap for automated user creation through X509 authentication with user authorization through LDAP, this feature allows for the automation of user creation. This strengthens operational efficiency and streamlines user management processes, ensuring a seamless integration of security protocols.

Support for Azure Private Link

Over the past quarters, there have already been announcements about different private IP endpoint service deliveries. From Q3 2025 on, SAP HANA Cloud now supports Azure Private Link as well, enabling users to connect applications running within an Azure landscape to SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database using private IP endpoints. These endpoints are addressable only within the Azure network and are not exposed publicly, ensuring an additional layer of security. It is important to note that services in SAP HANA Cloud already enforce strict transport layer security (TLS) and allow users to configure IP allow or disallow lists.

With Azure Private Link support, users can significantly reduce the exposure of IP endpoints, enhancing the overall security of connections to SAP HANA Cloud. This feature complements existing IP allow or disallow list filtering, ensuring that sensitive data remains protected and secure within the Azure network.

Multi-Model Data Processing

Vector Embedding SQL Function Support for Generative AI Hub

With the recent release, SAP HANA Cloud once again expands its vector embedding support by allowing the VECTOR_EMBEDDING SQL function to directly use embedding models exposed via SAP GenAI Hub. 

Previously, the function only supported SAP-provided NLP models. Now, customers can connect their own SAP GenAI Hub service instance and consume any available embedding model, for example OpenAI, Amazon Titan, or other partner models directly via SQL. 

All one must do is:

  • Create a remote source in SAP HANA Cloud that points to your SAP GenAI Hub (AI Core) service instance 
  • Configure certificates and authentication controls 
  • Retrieve available models with GET_REMOTE_SOURCE_AI_MODELS built-in procedure 
  • Call VECTOR_EMBEDDING by passing the text, type (e.g. DOCUMENT), model name and version, and the remote source 

For detailed setup and examples, see here. 

Support for Batch Embedding Creation using CREATE VECTOR EMBEDDINGS

SAP HANA Cloud also introduces a newly built-in procedure CREATE_VECTOR_EMBEDDINGS that makes it easier to generate vector embeddings for large volumes of text data stored in SAP HANA tables. Instead of having to process documents row by row, this procedure lets you embed text in batches. You simply provide the table and column that contain your documents, specify the target vector column, choose the NLP model, and the procedure automatically generates embeddings where they are missing. 

This new capability simplifies and accelerates the integration of AI and NLP use cases with SAP HANA Cloud, by reducing time to value for building intelligent applications with embeddings and by allowing developers to process large datasets more efficiently with built-in batch handling. It also eliminates repetitive boilerplate code for embedding creation and storage. 

To summarize, this makes SAP HANA Cloud a more powerful foundation for scenarios such as semantic search, generative AI, and intelligent text analysis. For detailed syntax and examples, see here. 

JSON as a datatype in the SAP HANA Cloud JSON Document Store

With QRC3 2025, SAP HANA Cloud introduces JSON as a datatype in the Document Store. This is not a column data type for tables, but a return type for collections in the Document Store. 

Collections can now return JSON directly instead of NVARCHAR, so queries follow JSON semantics without extra casting. This brings clearer path access with the $ root specifier, better performance through filter and function pushdown, and simpler syntax when working with JSON content. 

By making JSON a first class return type, SAP HANA Cloud improves both efficiency and consistency when building applications on flexible document data. For detailed syntax and examples, see here.

Please note, the ‚Äò$‚Äô document root specifier is mandatory for collections returning JSON. Existing collections will still default to NVARCHAR unless explicitly created or altered to return JSON. Some casts (like TO_NVARCHAR on complex types) are restricted for JSON return types.  

Graphical View Modeling

The third release in 2025 again brings many enhancements to SAP HANA Cloud‚Äôs graphical view modeling capabilities. Below, we are giving an overview about the innovations introduced. To get more details, you can take a closer look at Jan Zwickel's blog post.

Ability to rename multiple already mapped columns

Let‚Äôs start with the new ability to rename multiple columns that are already mapped, allowing users to perform this action in a single step. This feature is available for star joins and in the node mapping dialog.

This new capability simplifies the refactoring of column names and enhances model insights by enabling users to provide more-specific and meaningful column names. This increases the clarity and usability of data models, improving overall user experience.

Flexibly maintaining labels for alias names

Additionally, users can now flexibly maintain labels for alias names by using expressions. For example, users can generate a label that transforms the alias name to lowercase and adds a prefix.

This feature not only increases development efficiency and improves model quality but also provides a better analytics user experience by ensuring that labels are consistent and meaningful, eventually enhancing the readability and interpretability of data models.

Support of semijoin functionality

Furthermore, the semijoin functionality is now available. This feature enables users to effectively reduce records based on filter values by providing a dedicated join option for filtering in standard join nodes.

The semijoin functionality optimizes resource consumption when filtering through joins, allowing users to more efficiently manage data processing tasks. It enhances performance and ensures that only relevant data is processed, leading to improved overall efficiency and resource utilization.

Switching between structured privileges and structured filters through a graphical editor

Next, we introduced the capability to switch between structured privileges and structured filters using a graphical editor. Users can now change from one object type to another seamlessly and store the changes accordingly.

This increases flexibility when creating analytic privileges, allowing users to easily switch between privilege types to meet their specific requirements. The graphical editor enhances the overall usability and efficiency of managing data insights.

Improved supportability by SQL plan trace for EPM, MDS, and prepared statement caches

Moreover, supportability for SAP HANA Cloud got improved by enabling SQL plan trace for EPM (Enterprise Performance Management) queries, MDS (Multidimensional Services) queries, and prepared statement caches. 

By enabling plan trace for EPM, MDS queries, and prepared statement caches, this feature allows for better troubleshooting and performance analysis. It increases the overall supportability and reliability of these systems, ensuring that users can get the assistance they need when issues arise.

MDS Cubes

Support of input parameters in multidimensional services (MDS) cubes

With the Q3 release, users can now select combinations of input parameter values that will be loaded and served by the MDS cube. This functionality extends the capabilities of MDS cubes, allowing for more flexible and dynamic data insights.

The support for input parameters in MDS cubes increases the scope of scenarios that can be handled, providing users with more comprehensive and tailored insights. Thus, this feature helps users receive insights more quickly, enhancing the overall analytics experience and improving operational efficiency of SAP HANA Cloud.

Using additional currency conversion options with MDS cube

Besides, the recent release enables the use of additional currency conversion options with MDS cubes. Users can now employ rounding, decimal shifts, and the accuracy option "retain all possible digits" in conjunction with MDS cubes.

These additional currency conversion options simplify the creation of MDS cubes from existing calculation views while providing greater flexibility and control over currency data, and ensuring accurate and consistent financial insights.

Using unit conversion of MDS cube measures together with the option to convert at query execution time

Additionally, users are now able to convert units of MDS cube measures during query execution time.

By allowing the unit conversion at query execution time, users gain increased control over when and how unit conversion happens thus enhancing the flexibility and accuracy of data analysis, while also ensuring that units are converted as needed for specific insights.

 

Innovations in SAP HANA Cloud, data lake

Single Sign on support for SAP HANA Cloud, data lake files

The Data Lake Files app in SAP HANA Cloud Central now supports Single Sign-On (SSO) in addition to X509 credentials for authentication.  

It can be enabled with the ‚ÄúEnable Single Sign-On for Data Lake Files‚Äù menu item from the actions menu in either the Instances or Data Lake Files app. 

This feature enables users to quickly use the Data Lake Files app without having to do configuration steps required to use X509 authentication. 

 

Further Innovations & Enhancements

SAP HANA Client

Our SAP HANA Client for Python now supports Alpine Linux x64 as of the 2.25 release.  Alpine Linux is a security-oriented, lightweight Linux distribution.  Alpine Linux offers several benefits, such as faster build times due to its lightweight nature and enhanced security with fewer vulnerabilities due to its minimalism.   

However, unlike most Linux distributions, Alpine Linux uses musl libc instead of glibc. While this keeps Alpine lean, it breaks compatibility with the regular Linux x64 SAP HANA Client package and requires its own separate Python wheel release.  It can be found on PyPI at https://pypi.org/project/hdbcli/ 

For further details on the platforms that the SAP HANA Client supports, please see SAP Note 3165810 - SAP HANA Client Supported Platforms 

Expanded Data Center Availability on SAP Cloud Infrastructure in Germany

With QRC3 2025, we are introducing SAP HANA Cloud on SAP Cloud Infrastructure (SCI) ‚Äî SAP's own cloud infrastructure, operated in SAP data centers. This new deployment option expands the existing SAP HANA Cloud offering on leading hyperscaler infrastructure (AWS, Azure, GCP, and AliCloud) and meets the growing demand for technological independence, local compliance, and data control. 

Today, SAP HANA Cloud is available on SCI in Frankfurt, Germany. With EU-Access, in-country hosting, and enterprise-grade SLAs, this region offers compliance, security, and reliability for German and European customers. Additional SCI regions are planned for upcoming releases. Check SAP HANA Cloud Data Center Availability in SAP Roadmap Explorer. 

To learn more about SAP HANA Cloud on SCI, take a look at this this blog post.  

Database Application Development

Natural language to SQL generation in Joule using SAP Build Code

Last but not least, we introduce the generation of SQL for SAP HANA Cloud in Joule using SAP Build Code. This feature allows users to generate SQL statements based on natural language input. Additionally, it copies the generated SQL statement to the SQL consoles of the database explorer extension for SAP HANA in SAP Build Code.

This feature increases developer productivity by automating the process of generating SQL statements through natural language input. It reduces the likelihood of errors and improves the quality of the generated SQL, ultimately streamlining the development process and enhancing efficiency.

Great job reading through the entire Q3 2025 What's New blog post!

To dive deeper into the technical specifics of the Q3 2025 release, be sure to check out our What‚Äôs New Viewer in the Technical documentation. It offers a detailed overview of the release scope. To stay updated on the latest developments and news surrounding SAP HANA Cloud, follow the SAP HANA Cloud tag.

Additionally, you can discover our latest blog posts by searching for the #whatsnewinsaphanacloud hashtag. If you missed the previous What‚Äôs New webinar from Q2 2025, you can find it along with past recordings and future webinars in this YouTube playlist. Our upcoming webcast on the Q3 innovations will be added to the same playlist soon.

Have questions about SAP HANA Cloud or want to discuss the new innovations? Feel free to post them in our SAP HANA Cloud Community Q&A or in the comments section below!

Cheers!

entry.title: BPM 2025 ‚Äî International Conference on Business Process Management
entry.content:
The International Conference on Business Process Management (BPM) is an annual A-ranked conference and one of the key venues for research in this field. The 23rd edition took place this year in Sevilla, marking the second time in recent years that the city has hosted the event. While the pandemic had previously forced the conference to be held fully online, this year it was successfully carried out on site. 

Almost 400 researchers and practitioners from 39 countries came together in Sevilla for one week. Alongside presentations of current research, the participants were offered a rich program of discussions and talks covering a wide range of perspectives on BPM.

Being on site also meant that they could engage in the supporting program, which included social events and guided tours through Sevilla‚Äôs history, complemented by opportunities to experience Spain‚Äôs food and drinks culture.

In the following, we provide an overview of the conference structure and the main topics that were addressed, before highlighting how SAP Signavio contributed to BPM‚Äôs academic community.


Hoang Vu (Senior Solution Manager) and Adrian Rebmann (Developer at Signavio.Next)  at the SAP Signavio stall

 

Topics @ BPM

The topics presented at the BPM conference cover the full scope of the field. This broad range is reflected in the conference structure, which consists of three main tracks, five forums, and a series of co-located workshops. The main tracks are organized around foundations, engineering, and management. The forums add further focus on general BPM, education, responsible BPM, technology, and the intersection of industry and society. In addition, eleven co-located workshops addressed more specific themes, such as AI, natural language processing (NLP), object-centric processes, visual analysis, and the internet of things. Across all these areas, participants could engage with peer-reviewed, state-of-the-art research. 
When looking across this program, several research directions stood out.

Prediction & Simulation
The program emphasized advances in predictive monitoring (calibrated uncertainty, object-centric prediction, transformer and temporal-graph methods) together with prescriptive uses grounded in simulation for what-if analysis, resource-aware decision support, and arrival-time/resource modeling.

Discovery
Research focused on improving discovery quality through multi-objective and metaheuristic approaches, richer representations for object-centric and timeline-based discovery, and calls for more rigorous experimentation and reproducibility to make discovery results comparable and deployable. 

Conformance Checking
Work on conformance checking focused on more expressive and efficient alignment techniques (including partial-order approaches), data-aware conformance for declarative process models, methods to summarize all optimal alignments, and treatments of stochastic and metric/temporal constraints to better match real-world process models. 

AI, LLMs and NLP
Including many of the workshop papers, AI and natural language technologies were a recurring focus. The contributions explored the use of LLMs for process modeling and prediction, extracting pathways from textual guidelines, and assessing different process model representations. Workshops and demos further highlighted chatbot-based assistants and copilots, underscoring the growing role of LLMs and NLP in automating and supporting BPM tasks.

 


Adrian Rebmann holding his Keynote at the NLP4BPM Workshop

 

SAP Signavio @ BPM

What stood out about SAP Signavio‚Äôs presence at the conference was its combination of sponsorship and academic contributions. SAP Signavio was one of the main sponsors of BPM 2025 and was present on site with a stall (see picture above). At the same time, it actively contributed to the academic program through research. In fact, across all of the key topics highlighted above, there were papers and presentations carried out in collaboration with SAP Signavio. 

Simulation: Lukas Kirchdorfer (PhD at Signavio.Next) and his co-authors presented two papers on modeling arrival times and evaluating simulation approaches. Additionally, together we showcased a demo about a web-based simulation tool created from a student project that received an honorable mention.

Discovery: Timotheus Kampik (Principal Scientist at SAP Signavio) co-authored a Journal-First paper about enhancing the timeline-based visualization of discovery approaches.

Conformance: As a former visiting researcher, Michael Grohs contributed to the conference with two papers from his work at SAP Signavio. One in collaboration with Adrian Rebman about detecting and a second one in collaboration with Nadine Cordes (Product Associate at SAP Global Content Group) about assessing undesired deviations in processes. 

AI, LLMs and NLP: Adrian Rebman delivered a keynote at the NLP4BPM workshop, presenting insights into the process understanding of LLMs and how they could impact products. In addition, Hoang Vu presented his paper about BPM for AgenticAI, for which he and his co-authors received the runner up for the Best Responsible BPM Forum Paper Award.

It's important to note that above, only former visiting researcher or SAP Signavio employees are named. These contributions were realized in collaboration with co-authors from various universities across Germany, Austria, and Sweden, which should not be forgotten, and are listed fully at the end of this post.
In addition to SAP Signavio‚Äôs contribution to this year‚Äôs BPM conference, we currently have two additional active contributors to the conference as Visiting Researchers within our research team. This will further broaden our network of collaborations and ensure that SAP Signavio continues to contribute to the community in the future.

 

Conclusion

BPM 2025 highlighted a field that is both well-established and still rapidly evolving. This was reflected in SAP Signavio‚Äôs contributions, which spanned simulation, discovery, conformance checking, and AI & NLP, connecting theoretical advances with practical applications.
For those interested in learning more about the details of the latest advancements in BPM, the majority of papers are already publicly available.

Looking ahead, the International Conference on Process Mining (ICPM) will be the next major opportunity to engage with these topics, and we will share a follow-up post with our participation and key takeaways.

 

References

  • Adrian Rebmann ‚Äî LLMs for BPM ‚Äî From First-Wave Features to Process Understanding and Lasting Impact (Keynote at NLP4BPM)
  • Christoffer Rubensson, Harleen Kaur, Timotheus Kampik and Jan Mendling ‚Äî  Timeline-based process Discovery (Journal First)
  • Hoang Vu, Nataliia Klievtsova, Henrik Leopold, Stefanie Rinderle-Ma and Timotheus Kampik ‚Äî Agentic Business Process Management: Practitioner's Perspectives on Agent Governance in Business Processes  (Responsible BPM Forum)
  • Jack Edh, Tuva Falk, Filip Kanon, Erik Simonsson, Hugo Sj√∂din, Jonatan Wincent, Elisabeth Barar, Robert Bl√ºmel, and Lukas Kirchdorfer ‚Äî A Business Process Simulation Tool Bridging Control-Flow and Resource-Centric  Paradigms) (Demos & Resouces)
  • Konrad √ñzdemir, Lukas Kirchdorfer, Keyvan Amiri Elyasi, Han van der Aa and Heiner Stuckenschmidt ‚Äî Rethinking Business Process Simulation: A Utility-Based Evaluation Framework (BPM Forum)
  • Lukas Kirchdorfer, Konrad √ñzdemir, Stjepan Kusenic, Han van der Aa and Heiner Stuckenschmidt‚Äî A Divide-and-Conquer Approach for Modeling Arrival Times in Business Process Simulation (Main Track)
  • Michael Grohs, Nadine Cordes and Jana-Rebecca Rehse ‚Äî A Procedural Framework for Assessing the Desirability of Process Deviations (Main Track)
  • Michael Grohs, Adrian Rebmann and Jana-Rebecca Rehse ‚Äî Detecting Undesired Process Behavior by Means of Retrieval Augmented Generation (BPM Forum)

entry.title: Drones + SAP PM: A Practical Case in Wind Turbine Maintenance
entry.content:
Hi folks! This is my first post in the community, and I‚Äôd like to share a project our team worked on. First, a bit of context: the company I work for is an SAP implementation partner (we‚Äôve been on this journey for about 20 years!), and this project was for a U.S.-based energy company that operates in several countries. In this case, the work was done in a LATAM country. 

It was a really exciting project because it had the potential to impact millions of people. Basically, the company needed to improve the process of inspecting wind turbines, digitize a process that had been fully manual, and integrate that data with the PLM Enterprise Asset Management (EAM)/Plant Maintenance (PM) module. And when I say it was a high-impact project, I mean it: the energy produced by these turbines was feeding the power grid for about 40 million households. 

There were two main aspects we needed to optimize through technology. The first was the inspection process itself. These turbines are massive (over 500 feet tall - around 150 meters), which made manual inspection both extremely dangerous for operators and very time-consuming, not to mention dependent on favorable weather conditions. 

The second was ensuring uninterrupted service, to avoid power outages that could affect people‚Äôs daily lives and harm the local economy. 

Our solution was implemented in three phases: 

Phase 1: Drones 
Together with the client, we defined which drone to purchase, considering flight autonomy, battery life, weight, and software compatibility to connect with the app we developed in the next phase. These drones were equipped with high-resolution cameras to capture detailed images and videos of every part of the turbines. 

Phase 2: App development 
We built an app for field technicians to document inspections with photos and videos. The app includes machine learning image recognition models trained to identify wear, cracks, or other anomalies. Based on those findings, technicians could generate and execute work orders directly from the device. The app works both online and offline, which is key since turbines are often located in remote areas with poor connectivity. 

Phase 3: SAP PM integration 
The app was integrated with SAP Plant Maintenance (PM) so that detected defects automatically created repair orders. This eliminated manual steps and ensured that the data captured in the field flowed directly into the maintenance process. 

To keep it short, here are some of the results we achieved with the team at Inclusion Cloud: 

  • Work-related incidents during inspections were reduced by almost 50%. 
  • Inspection time was reduced by 35%. 
  • Data input errors dropped by 99%. 

I hope you find this project interesting! I‚Äôd also love to hear if anyone here has worked on something similar.

entry.title: Strengthening Fairness and Consistency in AI-Enabled Features
entry.content:
Credits: Yasmin Dwiputri & Data Hazards Project / https://betterimagesofai.org / https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/

The information provided in this blog post is for general informational purposes only and does not constitute legal advice. Readers should consult with qualified legal professionals regarding any specific questions or concerns related to regulatory compliance or other obligations.

At SAP, we‚Äôre continually working to ensure that our AI-enabled features perform reliably and responsibly across diverse use cases.

Since the introduction of our SAP Global AI Ethics Policy and the launch of our AI Ethics Assessment process in 2022, we‚Äôve implemented evaluation practices that help identify and address unintended outcomes in development.

To support this effort, we partnered with SAP SuccessFactors to explore practical ways of evaluating AI-enabled features. This collaboration led to the creation of internal resources to help guide teams through these evaluations.

Below, you‚Äôll find answers to some frequently asked questions from our teams working with these evaluation practices.

What are inconsistent outcomes in AI systems and how do they relate to fairness or bias?Inconsistent outcomes in AI systems ‚Äì often referred to as bias ‚Äì refer to measurable differences in how individuals or groups are treated. These differences can arise from data or design choices that unintentionally influence model behavior. For example, if an AI system produces different results based on certain characteristics ‚Äì such as age, gender, or other demographic factors ‚Äì it may be treating people unfairly. When these patterns persist and lead to unequal performance or decision-making, they raise concerns about fairness. Ensuring that AI systems deliver fair and consistent outcomes across diverse user groups is key to building trust and avoiding unintended harm.
What are ‚Äòproxy variables‚Äô in AI evaluations? When evaluating AI systems for fairness and consistent outcomes, it‚Äôs important to consider how certain personal attributes can appear in data either directly or indirectly: 
  • Direct descriptors are data points that explicitly identify a personal attribute, e.g., a date of birth revealing the age of a person. 
  • Indirect descriptors or proxy variables are data points that may not directly identify a personal attribute but that are strongly correlated with it. For example, a name may suggest national origin; or a combination of gender and age may imply pregnancy likelihood.

Fairness is a widely recognized principle in Data Protection and Privacy (DPP) frameworks. To uphold fairness in AI systems, it‚Äôs essential to test AI systems for both types of variables. This helps ensure that AI systems behave consistently across different user groups.

Which type of testing is appropriate for identifying inconsistent outcomes in an AI system?The types of testing needed to evaluate inconsistent outcomes depends on the type of AI that is being leveraged and its intended use case. 

A key consideration is whether your team is developing their own Narrow AI (i.e., non-Generative-AI) model or whether they leverage a 3rd party foundation model such as large language models (LLMs). When working with 3rd party LLMs, it may be appropriate to treat them as black boxes for testing purposes since the underlying data and model properties (architecture, training process, objective function, etc.) are often not accessible. In these cases, testing can focus on evaluating outputs across different scenarios and user groups to detect potential inconsistencies. In contrast, when it comes to Narrow AI systems developed in-house, training data and model design choices can be reviewed to identify patterns that may lead to inconsistent outcomes. This allows for more targeted evaluations, such as inspecting data distributions and identifying systemic performance disparities across demographic groups.

How can Narrow AI models be tested for consistent outcomes?When evaluating AI systems for consistent outcomes, it's helpful to consider three distinct approaches:
  • Individual consistency: Similar individuals should receive similar results.
  • Group outcome consistency: Outcome distribution should be balanced across demographic groups.
  • Group performance consistency: Prediction quality (e.g., error rates) should be comparable across groups.

To understand whether differences in AI results are meaningful, statistical significance tests can be conducted. These tests validate whether any observed inconsistencies are likely real or random.

Together, these tests help ensure AI systems deliver consistent and reliable performance.

How many test cases are needed to evaluate an AI system for fairness and consistency?The number of test cases depends on the specific use case, the types of outcome variability, and the evaluation method. As a general guideline, test datasets should be balanced and reflect the diversity found in real-world data. For instance, when evaluating how an AI system responds to names associated with different genders, include a balanced and varied set of name types to ensure reliable coverage. In some cases, sample size testing can help determine whether a dataset is large enough to detect meaningful differences in system behavior across user groups. The goal is to build confidence that the AI performs consistently and predictably across varied scenarios.

entry.title: Using a Matrix Score as a rating in Compensation Integration
entry.content:
We are using Performance Management forms where we capture all four ratings: Objectives, Competencies, Potential, and Overall Performance. As far as I know, these are the only ratings that can be directly integrated into Compensation to drive merit or adjustment guidelines.

In our customer scenario, the merit increase is determined based on a matrix score that combines the Potential and the Performance rating. This matrix score is then used in Compensation to decide the increase.

Is there a standard way to bring such rating (matrix score) from the Performance form into Compensation and use it in the same way as the standard ratings? Or is it only possible to use the four delivered ratings (Objectives, Competencies, Potential, Overall Performance) for the Performance‚ÄìCompensation integration?

entry.title: Re: Cannot connect Fully Activated Appliance to GCP
entry.content:
Hi justinifountain3425,

Please check your global CPUs quota (All Regions). In case that is not enough (lower than 44 in your case), this is the root cause of your problem and you must adjust it to be able to create an appliance via SAP Cloud Appliance Library.

As it is described in GCP documentation, some new accounts and projects have a global CPUs (All Regions) quota. That quota applies to all regions and is measured as a sum of all your vCPUs in all regions.
For example, if you have 48 vCPUs remaining in a single region such as us-central1 but only 32 vCPUs remaining for the CPUs (All Regions)quota, you can launch only 32 vCPUs in the us-central1 region, even though there is remaining quota in the region. This is because you reach the vCPUs (All Regions) quota and need to delete existing instances before you can launch new instances or to adjust your current global CPUs (All Regions) quota.

Best regards,

Tsvetinka

entry.title: Understanding the 'ERP Connector Queue'
entry.content:
The 'ERP Connector Queue' is a feature within the FSM Admin interface that displays the current transfer status of messages or objects being processed between SAP Field Service Management (FSM) and the ERP system. This feature allows users to track the location of messages, determining whether they have been sent from the Cloud to the ERP system or are currently being processed.

Accessing the 'ERP Connector Queue'

To access the 'ERP Connector Queue', follow these steps:

  1. Go to the Admin interface.
  2. Navigate to 'Companies' and select the relevant FSM Company.
  3. Proceed to 'ERP Connector' and select 'ERP Connector Queue'.

Understanding the Queue

The queue provides a list of objects that may be in a BLOCKED sync status due to issues in data exchange with the backend system. Each entry in the queue includes:

  • ID: Unique identifier (Message ID) of the message.
  • Created At: Timestamp indicating when the message was created.

Unblocking Objects

Please refer to our SAP Knowledge Base Article about 3551527 - How to unblock Objects in SAP Field Service Management? and 3444543 - Root Cause of BLOCKED objects in SAP Field Service Management.

Important Notes

  • Familiarize yourself with the implications of deleting records before proceeding.
  • Understanding the BLOCKED object mechanism is crucial for effective management of the ERP Connector Queue.

entry.title: CDS view based CDC enabled Extractor is not working on ANLC
entry.content:
Hi Team,

In order to build a CDC enabled CDS View-based Data Extractor for ANLC table we have tried the following approaches but failed.
Is there any way available to build this, please guide?
Also, why there is such restrictions in place for enabling delta extractions?

  1. Building the CDS view on ANLC Table. It does not work. The data extraction/data pre-view also does not work. We checked few blogs and tried our luck on the view faav_anlc.
  2. Building the CDS view on faav_anlc view. The data extraction works only in full mode. The delta mode of extraction does not work with "delta.changeDataCapture.automatic : true". So, we tried with manually defining the elements.
  3. Building the CDS view by manually defining the delta elements. Using this the delta extraction fails because the view - faav_anlc has AMDP table functions and CDC does not support that.

entry.title: Re: bapi_pr_create return error

Use a standard tool to convert received data to internal expected format

CALL FUNCTION 'CONVERSION_EXIT_ALPHA_INPUT'
  EXPORTING
    input  = ls_upload-asset_no
  IMPORTING
    output = ls_praccount-asset_no.
* Recent versions
ls_praccount-asset_no = |{ ls_upload-asset_no ALPHA = IN }|.

entry.title: Re: Multiple listpickers
entry.content:
Hi @Jitendra_Kansal78,

The listpickers are not depending on each other.
May be simple example: adding a part in SSAM by clicking on the add button in WorkOrderDetail page.

What I want:
When I choose an order from the pickerlist I want the Operation pickerlist be opened so I can choose directly an operation.
So simple open the operation listpicker to choose from.

What I currently must do:
When I choose the order from the orderlist picker:
    I need to click on the Operation listpicker to see the list of operations.
    After that I can click on the operation to choose the operation.

And maybe you think, what a lazy user.
And yes, you are correct, but realise this is just a simple example.
When there are 5 listpickers on the screen and all are mandatory saves you 5 clicks.
And when the user must add 50 objects it saves him/her 50x5 clicks = 250 clicks.

Regards,
Patrick Willems

entry.title: Re: Required BADI For Billing Document VF01 For Validatio...
entry.content: The main enhancement spot for billing creation is BAdI: SD_BIL_DATA_TRANSFER. This BAdI is triggered during billing document creation (VF01 / Fiori ‚ÄúCreate Billing Documents‚Äù). It allows you to validate or enrich data before the billing document is saved. However, please note it is item‚Äëlevel and called once per item. If you need to validate across all items (e.g. completeness checks), you must buffer the items in a global class and then perform your validation once the last item is processed. SAP Community experts recommend using a singleton buffer class for this purpose. Similar requirement has already been discussed here where this point is highlighted

entry.content: Error Occurred during reprint processing via tcode VF31 for SAP Billing Doc- output type RD00.Getting the error as table row is greater than 176cm. On checking with technical team, they mentioned that in a single row, it is trying to print 433 serial numbers (line items) which is more than SAP standard limit allowed. they have checked the execution, and it is allowing 381 serial numbers only. Please suggest a workaround for this case to solve the issue.

entry.title: Re: How can I settle a single customer in multiple custom...
entry.content:
Hi @ramuy, 

WB2R_DOC_ENTRY will be the only solution to post a Settlement document for a single customer in a multiple customer contract. 
You will have to activate the manual settlement document creation for this contract type. 

That's one of the biggest downside of using a Multiple customer contract type, it's all or nothing: create the settlement document for all relevant customer or nothing; reverse the settlement documents for all relevant customers for the same settlement date or nothing. 
This is to avoid any inconsistency for business volume selection and calculation/posting. 


Regards, 
Gauthier VICTOR

entry.title: Q3 2025 Innovations: SAP Enterprise Service Management
entry.content:
Welcome to the quarterly innovation highlights for  SAP Enterprise Service Management for Q3 2025.  Here, I want to feature some key capabilities that have been released within the last three months. We invite you to register for our Q3 2025 Innovations webcast on October 14th to stay updated on further details of our latest innovations and improvements.

Please also join us at the upcoming Customer Experience Connect where we showcase how the latest AI-infused SAP CX solutions optimize operations, generate action-ready insights, and deliver delightful experiences at every step of the customer journey.

Learn more about the latest Q3  innovations across our CX portfolio here SAP CX: What‚Äôs New in Q3 2025 | SAP News Center 

.What‚Äôs New in SAP Enterprise Service Management
SAP Enterprise Management innovations streamline workflows and speed resolution in a single workspace. Tight integration with the SAP Business Suite and embedded AI deliver clearer service insights and automate manual handoffs, reducing costs and minimizing errors. Improved user experience and greater automation accelerate resolution times, lower operating expenses, and strengthen SLA adherence and customer satisfaction. Together, these advances shorten time-to-value for new services, free capacity, reduce risk, and boost organizational agility and competitive advantage. Below are the highlights:

Dispute Management with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Achieve quick time to value with AI-based data extraction from customer emails integrated with FI-AR Dispute Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This automates and streamlines dispute creation and resolution time, driving down operational costs.

Tab Grouping in Agent Desktop: Complex inquires often require several elements of contextual data that can create many open tabs. Allowing tabs to be grouped under a corresponding main session simplifies the user workspace eliminating screen clutter and boosting efficiency.

First level case categorization with Business Information Extraction: Achieve immediate operational efficiency and increased accuracy using business information extraction for first level case categorization enabling quick time to value from AI driven case categorization. Based on the Case subject and description, the LLM model classifies it under one of the matching category values from the ones configured in grouping or class.

Case Summary enhancements: Sentiment trend and sentiment graph can now be enabled in the interaction summary for additional context. Internal and/or external case notes can also be used to generate the resolution summary.

Full-screen Case Create: Service professionals can expand to full-screen from the quick create for easier visibility and convenience when creating a case.

Filter case list by custom parties: With SAP Enterprise Management spanning many use cases within an organization personalization and context is key for service professionals and managers. When providing service for various stakeholders such as a business account, employee or supplier, the case list is easily adapted for the need.

Filter emails by channel in email work center: With many email addresses maintained by customers for different stakeholders, either internal employees, suppliers, customers, etc., managers and supervisors are able to easily view the interactions coming into their teams such as  finance, sales, HR, facilities or security and compliance. This provides simplicity as well as clear visibility at supervisory levels.

 
Template visibility and restrictions: Manage email templates with ease and ensure contextual templates are available for the right departments and resources furthering governance in managing templates. 
 
Form Auto-Fill Actions: Data from backend systems (SAP & 3rd party) can easily be pulled to prepopulate form fields. This reduces time to create a request or case and removes manual entry that can be error prone.
 
 
Custom Services: Gain more flexibility and extend your capabilities without modifying the core application.  Integrate external functionality easily ensuring unified service processes and resolution from one place.

 

Additional Resources 

For more information and complete details on the most recent innovations and improvements check our What's New page on help.sap.com updated monthly.

 

Please share your feedback in a comment and follow our SAP Sales and Service Cloud topic page to connect with the community!

entry.title: Re: Error Occurred during reprint processing via TCode VF...
entry.content:
Why it is happening in your case is because, in your RD00 output form, all serial numbers are being concatenated into one table row (one cell). With 433 serial numbers, the text block grows taller than the maximum allowed row height. That‚Äôs why it works up to ~381 serials (fits within 176 cm), but fails beyond that. It‚Äôs a standard Smart Forms limitation.

Some workarounds are

  • Instead of printing all serials in a single cell, design the form to loop over serial numbers and print them line by line. In Smart Forms, replace the table cell with a loop node that outputs one serial per row. This way, the form generates multiple rows, each well within the height limit.
  • If business insists on a ‚Äúblock‚Äù of serials, split them into multiple columns (e.g. 10 serials per row √ó 44 rows). This reduces row height drastically.
  • Implement logic to page‚Äëbreak after a certain number of serials (e.g. 300 per page). Remaining serials print on the next page, avoiding the 176 cm overflow.
